ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a broad variety of laboratory techniques (Western Blot, IHC, RT-PCR, H/E staining) that could be applied in studying research questions related to reproductive biology and reproductive tissues. In addition, I learned how to analyze quantitative data related to statistics, and to be more comfortable with utilizing microscopy to analyze reproductive tissues.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the lab lectures a lot and the homework was good. I just had a hard time seeing the protocols and I wish they were posted before the labs so I could read it beforehand.

The course was well organized by lab techniques. But, since many of these techniques have long incubation times, we sometimes sat around without an explicit task to do. If we could do a more formal/fleshed out journal club during hour long waits, for example, it might be a good way to continuously engage students with both hands-on and more conceptual work. Also, I wish that we had more time to do more comprehensive journal clubs, since we usually only got to discuss lab techniques + one or two figures rather than talk about data analysis and implications for the reproductive biology field as a whole.
Great in person, fun lab class- highly recommend

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Taught in person, which is ideal
Overall it was very good and I appreciate Professor W doing the class during the pandemic.

The professors made an effort to include anyone who was calling into the in-person lab by Zoom, which I really appreciated. The hybrid Zoom courses (especially for the talks from physician-scientists) were also really nice. Because there were limited shared equipment and sinks in the room, however, the workflow was not always efficient since we had to socially distance. Despite these resource-based obstacles, the class was still well organized.
I personally was super grateful to have an in-person class, so I was excited that this class was generally in-pesron

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Excellent MCDB lab for seniors
If you're looking for a lab course and you are an MCDB senior, I recommend taking this course.
YES! This is a fantastic lab.

Absolutely, this was by far my favorite lab class at Yale, and I learned so much without ever feeling stressed or overwhelmed. Professor Whirledge clearly cares about her students' education and tries very hard to support their learning whenever she can.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Mostly in-person lab, with some virtual Zoom class components
